awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CI-Team Implementation Project: The Signal Processing Education Network
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
A goal of this project was to create the Signal Processing Education Network (SPEN), a community of people who teach signal processing and equip them with tools to share their teaching materials.  Through a series of workshops, it was decided that SPEN should address three primary goals:

  1. Serve as a forum to exchange best practices and tools for developing new signal processing education content;
  2. Develop an inventory and wish list for teaching a range of signal processing courses;
  3. Develop a globe-spanning network that will work to strengthen and unify signal processing education through interactive content.

The bulk of the work was spent creating and testing the content used by the the tools developed by the other teams to make SPEN a reality.

Two tools were created:  Quadbase, a repository of signal processing questions and OpenStax Tutor, an on-line tool for delivering those questions to students. 

The outcomes are:

  1. Some 40+ interactive figures were created to teaching digital signal processing.
  2. Some 180+ questions, hints and solutions were written and entered into Quadbase.
  3. 44 students were enrolled in a class that used OpenStax Tutor to deliver homework and provide two types of feedback, just answers, or detailed explanations.  Those receiving detailed explanations did slightly better on the following exams, but not statistically significantly better.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2013
Modified by: Mark A Yoder
